quiz.title: Physics Grade 11: Forces on Horizontal Surfaces
quiz.subtitle: Unit 2 Quiz 2: Net Force, Friction & Connected Systems (10 Problems)
quiz.subject: Physics

questions.question: A 12 kg wooden crate is dragged across a warehouse floor using a rope that makes a 25° angle above the horizontal. The tension in the rope is 50 N, and the coefficient of kinetic friction between the crate and floor is 0.20. What is the crate's acceleration?
questions.explanation: Normal force N = mg - Tsinθ = (12×9.8) - (50×sin25°) = 117.6 - 21.13 = 96.47 N. Kinetic friction f_k = μ_kN = 0.20×96.47 = 19.29 N. Horizontal component of tension = Tcosθ = 50×cos25° = 45.32 N. Net force = 45.32 - 19.29 = 26.03 N. Acceleration a = F_net/m = 26.03/12 = 2.17 m/s² ≈ 2.2 m/s².

questions.question: A 5.0 kg concrete block sits at rest on a level concrete floor. The coefficient of static friction between the block and floor is 0.40. What is the minimum horizontal push force required to make the block start sliding?
questions.explanation: The minimum force to overcome static friction is F_min = μ_s×N = μ_s×mg = 0.40×5.0×9.8 = 19.6 N. This is when the applied force just equals the maximum static friction force.

questions.question: Two cardboard boxes are connected by a light string on a frictionless table. Box A (4.0 kg) is pulled to the right with a force of 30 N. Box B (6.0 kg) is attached to Box A by the string. What is the tension in the connecting string?
questions.explanation: Total mass = 4.0 + 6.0 = 10.0 kg. System acceleration a = F/m_total = 30/10.0 = 3.0 m/s². The tension T is the force accelerating Box B, so T = m_B×a = 6.0×3.0 = 18.0 N.

questions.question: A warehouse worker pushes a 15 kg packing crate with a constant horizontal force of 60 N across a level concrete floor. The coefficient of kinetic friction is 0.25. What is the crate's acceleration?
questions.explanation: Normal force N = mg = 15×9.8 = 147 N. Kinetic friction f_k = μ_kN = 0.25×147 = 36.75 N. Net force F_net = applied force - friction = 60 - 36.75 = 23.25 N. Acceleration a = F_net/m = 23.25/15 = 1.55 m/s².

questions.question: A child pulls a 20 kg sled across snowy ground with an 80 N force directed 30° above the horizontal. The coefficient of kinetic friction between sled and snow is 0.15. What is the sled's acceleration?
questions.explanation: Vertical: N = mg - Fsinθ = (20×9.8) - (80×0.5) = 196 - 40 = 156 N. Friction f_k = μ_kN = 0.15×156 = 23.4 N. Horizontal component F_x = 80×cos30° = 69.28 N. Net force = 69.28 - 23.4 = 45.88 N. Acceleration a = 45.88/20 = 2.29 m/s².

questions.question: An 8.0 kg wooden block is pressed against a vertical brick wall with a 40 N horizontal force. The coefficient of static friction between wood and brick is 0.50. Which statement is correct about whether the block will slide down?
options: Yes, because maximum static friction (20 N) is less than the weight (78.4 N)
No, because friction (20 N) balances the weight
Yes, because the normal force (40 N) exceeds the weight
No, because the applied force (40 N) supports the block
questions.explanation: Weight = mg = 8.0×9.8 = 78.4 N downward. Maximum static friction f_s,max = μ_sN = 0.50×40 = 20 N upward. Since 20 N < 78.4 N, friction cannot balance the weight, so the block accelerates downward.

questions.question: Two boxes are stacked: a 3.0 kg box rests on a 7.0 kg box. A 25 N horizontal force is applied to the bottom box. μ_s between boxes = 0.30, μ_k between bottom box and floor = 0.20. Assuming no slipping between boxes, what is the system's acceleration?
questions.explanation: Total weight = (3+7)×9.8 = 98 N. Floor friction f_floor = μ_k×98 = 0.20×98 = 19.6 N. Net force on system = 25 - 19.6 = 5.4 N. Acceleration a = F_net/m_total = 5.4/10 = 0.54 m/s². Check: Force needed to accelerate top box = 3×0.54 = 1.62 N, which is less than max static friction between boxes (0.30×3×9.8 = 8.82 N), so no slip assumption valid.

questions.question: A 10 kg toolbox is pulled by two ropes: Rope 1 exerts 40 N at 30° above horizontal to the right; Rope 2 exerts 30 N at 20° below horizontal to the left. μ_k = 0.25. What is the magnitude of the toolbox's acceleration?
questions.explanation: Net F_x = 40cos30° - 30cos20° = 34.64 - 28.19 = 6.45 N right. Net F_y = 40sin30° - 30sin20° = 20.0 - 10.26 = 9.74 N up. Normal force N = mg - F_y,net = 98 - 9.74 = 88.26 N? Wait careful: Actually N = mg - upward forces = 98 - 9.74 = 88.26 N. Friction f_k = 0.25×88.26 = 22.07 N. Net horizontal force = 6.45 - 22.07 = -15.62 N (left). |a| = 15.62/10 = 1.56 m/s²? My earlier calc had different N. Let's recalc properly: Vertical: N + 40sin30° - 30sin20° - mg = 0 → N = mg - 40sin30° + 30sin20° = 98 - 20 + 10.26 = 88.26 N. Yes. f_k = 0.25×88.26 = 22.07 N. F_net,x = 6.45 - 22.07 = -15.62 N. |a| = 15.62/10 = 1.56 m/s². This differs from my earlier 1.05 m/s². Let me check original solution: In original, I had N = 67.74 N. That came from N = mg - F₁y + F₂y = 98 - 20 + (-10.26) = 67.74 N. That's correct because F₂y is downward (negative). So N = 67.74 N, f_k = 16.94 N, F_net,x = 6.45 - 16.94 = -10.49 N, |a| = 1.05 m/s². Correction made.

questions.question: A 6.0 kg block rests on a horizontal surface with μ_s = 0.45 and μ_k = 0.35. A force of 20 N is applied at 40° above the horizontal. Will the block move, and if so, what is its acceleration?
options: No, it remains stationary because horizontal component (15.3 N) < max static friction (20.7 N)
No, the vertical component lifts it off the surface
questions.explanation: F_x = 20cos40° = 15.32 N. F_y = 20sin40° = 12.86 N upward. Normal force N = mg - F_y = 58.8 - 12.86 = 45.94 N. Maximum static friction f_s,max = μ_sN = 0.45×45.94 = 20.67 N. Since 15.32 N < 20.67 N, the block doesn't move; static friction matches the applied horizontal component.

questions.question: A 25 kg shipping container is dragged along a factory floor with a rope making a 15° angle above horizontal. The tension is gradually increased until the container just begins to move at 120 N. What is the coefficient of static friction?
questions.explanation: At the threshold of motion: Horizontal: Tcosθ = μ_sN. Vertical: N = mg - Tsinθ = (25×9.8) - (120×sin15°) = 245 - 31.06 = 213.94 N. Then μ_s = Tcosθ/N = (120×cos15°)/213.94 = 115.91/213.94 = 0.542 ≈ 0.54.
